entry.title: Combined summary - Lamport scheme (not signature) to economize on L1
entry.summary:
Recent analysis reveals that using Pay-to-Taproot (P2TR) keypath spends with transactions containing an equal number of inputs and outputs can result in signatures consuming 14-16% of the transaction size. A proposed signature replacement scheme could free up to 16% of block space, but it faces challenges such as peer review, user acceptance, and the potential need for a hard fork.
A new cryptographic protocol reducing blockchain space by up to 66% has been developed, which simplifies transactions by not requiring the mining of public keys or broadcasting separate payloads. This protocol utilizes polynomial factorization in finite fields and is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/Yuri-SVB/FFM-cryptography/) for community engagement and is being considered for a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP).
A correction to the description of a function related to pre-image problems has been made, emphasizing the importance of accuracy in technical documentation. The corrected function pertains to mapping a LAMPPRI to a specific address and signature format.
The email outlines three scenarios addressing vulnerabilities in cryptographic schemes involving the LAMPPRI component. It evaluates strategies to keep collision rates low and discusses the trade-off between processing and storage requirements, considering the risk of double-spending attacks. It suggests that a multi-use scheme could help reduce blockchain bloat and enhance system efficiency.
Security concerns about chain reorganizations and double-spending attacks have been raised in light of proposed changes. There is a risk that attackers could redirect funds after a maturity period, potentially increasing the attack surface.
To combat rainbow-table attacks, adding nonce values from recent blocks as salts to introduce additional entropy has been proposed. This would increase security by adjusting computational expectations realistically.
Despite recommendations for hash functions to have a digest size twice that of the symmetric encryption key size, a suggestion to use 12-byte hashes to reduce block space by 26% was criticized for being less secure and vulnerable to evolving attack methods.
Optimizations like using 12-byte hashes for system efficiency are discussed, along with reducing fingerprint size to 128 bits and establishing fixed transaction intervals for finality. Comparing cryptographic signature schemes shows that Lamport without ECC publication and Taproot with Schnorr keys have similar on-chain impacts.
The proposed dual-key cryptographic framework for Bitcoin uses ECC and Lamport chains for signing, with a smart contract COMMITMENT mechanism to manage transactions securely. The model promotes single-use addresses and includes time-bound protections against unintended commitment execution.
Security of the system is highlighted by evaluating the economic unfeasibility of potential attacks, reinforced by assuming extreme cracking capabilities. Schnorr signatures' security adequacy is also considered, recognizing the need for more than 12 bytes of protection to safeguard digital assets.
References to contributions in cryptographic protocols demonstrate the ongoing efforts to improve digital currency security and efficiency, including work on Lamport chains and various signature schemes.
Finally, the integration of the Lamport Scheme into the transaction signing process is suggested to enhance byte-efficiency, potentially reducing blockchain data needs and introducing a penalty payment mechanism enforced within specified time frames. Argon2's memory-hard hashing function is recommended to allow smaller hash sizes, offering savings in blockchain data storage and processing.
